# TASK 1: DATA ACQUISITION
Loading in Global Top 10 from Netflix's TuDum Top 10. 
```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"

if(!dir.exists(file.path("data", "mp01"))){
    dir.create(file.path("data", "mp01"), showWarnings=FALSE, recursive=TRUE)
}

GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME <- file.path("data", "mp01", "global_top10_alltime.csv")

if(!file.exists(GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)){
    download.file("https://www.netflix.com/tudum/top10/data/all-weeks-global.tsv", 
                  destfile=GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)
}

COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME <- file.path("data", "mp01", "country_top10_alltime.csv")

if(!file.exists(COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME)){
    download.file("https://www.netflix.com/tudum/top10/data/all-weeks-countries.tsv", 
                  destfile=COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME)
}

if(!require("tidyverse")) install.packages("tidyverse")
library(readr)
library(dplyr)

GLOBAL_TOP_10 <- read_tsv(GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)
str(GLOBAL_TOP_10)
glimpse(GLOBAL_TOP_10)
```

# TASK 2: DATA CLEANING 
Global Top 10 has season titles with "N/A" values, which should be changed to NA instead.
```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"

# finds season_title with "N/A" values, changes it to NA, otherwise keep season_title
GLOBAL_TOP_10 <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
    mutate(season_title = if_else(season_title =="N/A", NA, season_title))
glimpse(GLOBAL_TOP_10)
```

# TASK 3: DATA IMPORT
Loading in Country-wide Top 10 from Netflix's TuDum Top 10.
```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"
COUNTRY_TOP_10 <- read_tsv(COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME, na = c("N/A"))
str(COUNTRY_TOP_10)
glimpse(COUNTRY_TOP_10)
```

# EXPLORATORY DATA ANALYISIS 
Reformating data tables to be more presentable and easier to follow. 
```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"
library(DT)
GLOBAL_TOP_10 |> 
    head(n=20) |>
    datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE))

# Creates the function format_titles with attribute of dataframe
library(stringr)
format_titles <- function(df){
    colnames(df) <- str_replace_all(colnames(df), "_", " ") |> str_to_title()
    df
}

GLOBAL_TOP_10 |> 
    format_titles() |> # Here's an example of using format_titles function
    head(n=20) |>
    datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE)) |>
    formatRound(c('Weekly Hours Viewed', 'Weekly Views'))

GLOBAL_TOP_10 |> 
    select(-season_title) |>
    format_titles() |>
    head(n=20) |>
    datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE)) |>
    formatRound(c('Weekly Hours Viewed', 'Weekly Views'))
    
GLOBAL_TOP_10 |> 
    mutate(`runtime_(minutes)` = round(60 * runtime)) |>
    select(-season_title, 
           -runtime) |>
    format_titles() |>
    head(n=20) |>
    datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE)) |>
    formatRound(c('Weekly Hours Viewed', 'Weekly Views'))
```

# Netflix has provided over 200 weeks of service for 93 countries but...
#### *Russia* who's service ended in 2022-02-27.
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"
# 6. Netflix provides over 200 weeks of service history for all but one country in our data set. Which country is this and when did Netflix cease operations in that country?

COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  group_by(country_name, week) |>
  summarize() |>
  mutate(first_week = first(week)) |>
  mutate(last_week = last(week)) |>
  distinct(country_name, .keep_all = TRUE) |>
  mutate(service_history_days = round(last_week - first_week)) |>
  mutate(service_history_weeks = as.numeric(round((service_history_days)/7))) |>
  arrange(service_history_weeks) |>
  format_titles() |>
  datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE))
```

# ðŸŽ¬ Red Notice views in 2021
#### *Red Notice* had **201,732,203** views in its first year of release. 
![](https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOGNjNGQ3MmItYTM5NS00NjBiLWI0ZTItZDE5ZjQyNjg3ODBjXkEyXkFqcGc@._V1_FMjpg_UX1000_.jpg)

# ðŸ“ˆ US #1 Films That Didnâ€™t Debut at the Top

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"
# 9. How many Films reached Number 1 in the US but did not originally debut there? 
# That is, find films that first appeared on the Top 10 chart at, e.g., Number 4 but 
# then become more popular and eventually hit Number 1 What is the most recent film to pull this off?

COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name %in% "United States") |>
  filter(category %in% "Films") |>
  group_by(show_title, week) |>
  summarize(weekly_rank) |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  mutate(debut_rank = first(weekly_rank)) |>
  mutate(growth = if_else(debut_rank > weekly_rank & weekly_rank == 1, TRUE, FALSE)) |>
  filter(growth == TRUE) |>  
  distinct(show_title, .keep_all = TRUE) |>
  format_titles() |>
  datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE))
```

### Throughout the Years
*Stranger Things* has proven itself to be timeless. As it remains to be a big hit since it's first release in 2016. Throughout the years, its success has kept climbing reaching an all time high in 2022. Now in 2025, Season 5 is believed to reach the same level of success. Until then, we'll see you on the other side.
```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"

library(ggplot2)    
library(ggtext)
st_data <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(show_title %in% "Stranger Things") |>
  group_by(season_title) |>
  summarize(views = sum(weekly_hours_viewed)) |>
  mutate(season_title = if_else(is.na(season_title), "Stranger Things 1", season_title)) |>
  mutate(views = views/1e6) |>
  mutate(season = c(2, 3, 4, 1)) |>
  arrange(season)
head(st_data)

#FORECAST
model <- lm(views ~ season, data = st_data)
summary(model)

predicted_s5 <- -394.9 + (454.7 *5)

st_data <- rbind(st_data , data.frame(season_title = "Stranger Things 5", views=predicted_s5, season=5))
head(st_data)

# BAR PLOT
ggplot(st_data, aes(x = season, y = views)) +
      geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill = "darkred") +
      labs(title = "Stranger Things Total Viewership per Season",
       y = "Views (in millions)",
       x = "Season") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_markdown(size = 20, face = "bold")
  )
```

```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"

# Hindi-language films and TV

# use this viewership data to estimate the size of Netflixâ€™s customer base in India: compute a few points and discuss the long term growth trends

# filling in NA values and CALCULATING TOTAL WEEKLY VIEWS BY YEAR
hindi_year <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(str_detect(show_title, "(Hindi)")) |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = runtime*60) |>
  mutate(year = format(week, "%Y")) |>
  select(week, year, show_title, weekly_hours_viewed, runtime_mins, runtime) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Sir (Hindi)", 99, runtime_mins))|>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "RRR (Hindi)", 186, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Thunivu (Hindi)", 146, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Kantara (Hindi)", 148, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "GodFather (Hindi)", 157, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Shabaash Mithu (Hindi)", 156, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Foot Fairy (Hindi)", 115, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Major (Hindi)", 146, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Raw (Hindi)", 155, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime_mins = if_else(show_title == "Radhe Shyam (Hindi)",138, runtime_mins)) |>
  mutate(runtime = runtime_mins/60) |>
  group_by(year) |>
  filter(year %in% c(2023, 2024)) |>
  mutate(estimated_weekly_views = weekly_hours_viewed/runtime) |>
  summarize(estimated_views = sum(estimated_weekly_views)) |>
  mutate(estimated_views = estimated_views/1e06)
  # format_titles() |>
  # datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE))

ggplot(hindi_year, aes(x = year, y = estimated_views)) +
    geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill = "orange") +
    labs(title = "Rise in Weekly Views in India",
     y = "Views (in millions)",
     x = "Year") +
theme_minimal() +
theme(
  plot.title = element_markdown(size = 20, face = "bold")
)
```
<br></br>

Looking at the trend over the past years, viewership has shown a modest rise. Although there's high variability due to outliers seen in 2022. # TASK 7: 3RD PRESS RELEASE

# COMING IN HOT 
Netflix hits the gas once more as *Formula 1: Drive to Survive* races into Season 8, premiering this March. Once again, taking viewers behind the scenes of the major events that has happened this past F1 season. Following the journey of the new set of rookies, highlights of jaw-dropping victories, and the drama that unfolds behind the hot seats. 

[![](https://miro.medium.com/1*BQaoAKsk1x0JgcEZBu9-mA.jpeg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wGXmiTzyp2k&pp=ygUTZjEgZHJpdmUgdG8gc3Vydml2ZQ%3D%3D)

### Hitting the Breaks... Can it Make a Comeback?
Although not shown in the dataset, *Formula 1: Drive to Survive: Season 1* aired back in 2019 and has since been renewed every year. However, viewership stats per season has seen a decline in the past seasons. Therefore, the question is: can season 8 surpass past seasons?
```{r, echo=TRUE, results='hide', message=FALSE}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"

# Totalling views per season
f1 <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(show_title %in% "Formula 1: Drive to Survive") |>
  mutate(season = str_sub(season_title,-1)) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarize(total_hours = sum(weekly_hours_viewed)/1e06) |> 
  arrange(desc(total_hours)) |> 
  glimpse()

# BAR PLOT
ggplot(f1, aes(x = season, y = total_hours)) +
      geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill = "slateblue") +
      labs(title = "F1: Drive to Survive Viewership per Season",
       y = "Views (in millions)",
       x = "Season") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_markdown(size = 20, face = "bold")
  )
```

### Undeniable Global Reach
F1 is one of the most globally accessible sports, broadcasted worldwide, as drivers race across the globe tackling tracks with some of the tightest turns at neck breaking speeds. For that reason, itâ€™s no surprise that the Netflix show has reached the Top 10 in so many countries. Aside from offering a behind the scene look at the season, the sports docuseries provides detailed recaps of each race for viewers who may have missed them live due to time zone differences. 
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show the code"
COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(show_title %in% "Formula 1: Drive to Survive") |>
  group_by(season_title) |>
  distinct(country_name) |>
  count(season_title) |>
  arrange(desc(n)) |>
  format_titles() |>
  datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE), colnames = c("Season", "Countries"))
```
